STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
January 2, 2024
Annette Ellison
INGHAM COUNTY YOUTH CENTER
700 E JOLLY RD,
LANSING, MI, 48910-6832
Re: License #: CO330201191
Dear Ms. Ellison:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
12/19/2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616) 204- 6992.
Sincerely,
Cathrine Raftery, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
COF Rule 400.10113 Employee records
• (1) Employee records shall be maintained for
each employee and shallinclude all of the
following information: (f) A written evaluation of
the employee's performance within the first 6
months of each position designated by these
rules and annually thereafter.
Three of the sixteen new employees did not meet the rule of the written evaluation
completed within the first six months of employment. Two of the three were
2

completed after the six months date and one of the three was missing the
evaluation.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Consultant provided feedback on having consistency as it pertains to the location
of the staff new hire tuberculosis screening. Some of the staff had their
tuberculosis screenings in their human resources and some were located within
another file within the medical department.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultant provided feedback on having consistency as it pertains to the hire
checklist with making sure it if filled out completely with the due date of the six-
month staff evaluation. It was also suggested for there to be consistency of the
form used for the six-month staff evaluations. During this period of review there
was some changes to the form, but it was not consistent throughout the new hire
files.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The facility has had 1 special investigation during this period under review with 1
resulting in a corrective action plan. The noncompliance noted a violation within the
storage and dispensing of medication to youth at the facility. The facility's corrective
action plan compliance is monitored quarterly. The facility has been in compliance
with meeting the expectations of the set deadlines of action steps within their
corrective action plans.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's
budget and the agency's financial audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable
Chief Administrator Assessment
Not Applicable
3

Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff interviews were conducted during the inspection and staff noted they enjoy
their jobs. They reported feeling an adequate amount of training and support from
upper management. Staff reported the facility has been really focusing on more
trauma informed care for the youth they serve.
Three youth were interviewed during the inspection. They reported feeling safe at
the facility and having a positive relationship with staff. The youth indicated no
concerns with restraints they have observed or been in with staff. All the youth
interviewed reported they feel like their grievances are taken seriously when they
report one. The only complaint the youth noted was that it has been difficult for their
probation officers to find their next long-term residential placement which makes
them frustrated.
Description of Agency Walk Through
An on-site inspection and walkthrough of the facility occurred on December 19,
2023. There were no issues or safety concerns noted.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
12/21/2023
